content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="C H 3 O H, gas, is in equilibrium with C O, gas, plus 2 H 2, gas. Delta H naught equals 90.0 kilojoules per mole of reaction." overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>CH</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <mi>OH</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>⇄</mo> <mi>CO</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <msub> <mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"> </mspace> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <mi>H</mi> <mo>°</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mn>90.0</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mi>kJ</mi> <mo>/</mo> <msub> <mi>mol</mi> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> </msub> </math>

Methanol vapor decomposes to form carbon monoxide gas and hydrogen gas at high temperatures in the presence of a platinum catalyst, as represented by the balanced chemical equation given.

(a) Are the hydrogen atoms oxidized or are they reduced in the forward reaction? Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="C H 3 O H, gas, is in equilibrium with C O, gas, plus 2 H 2, gas. Delta H naught equals 90.0 kilojoules per mole of reaction." overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>CH</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <mi>OH</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>⇄</mo> <mi>CO</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <msub> <mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"> </mspace> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <mi>H</mi> <mo>°</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mn>90.0</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mi>kJ</mi> <mo>/</mo> <msub> <mi>mol</mi> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> </msub> </math>

Methanol vapor decomposes to form carbon monoxide gas and hydrogen gas at high temperatures in the presence of a platinum catalyst, as represented by the balanced chemical equation given.

(a) Are the hydrogen atoms oxidized or are they reduced in the forward reaction? Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.
(b) In the following box, draw the complete Lewis electron-dot diagram for the carbon monoxide molecule in which every atom obeys the octet rule. Show all bonding and nonbonding valence electrons.

(c) The values of the standard molar entropies of the compounds involved in the reaction are given in the following table.

Substance
 <math alttext="S naught, in joules per kelvin mole" overflow="scroll"><mi>S</mi><mo>°</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mfenced><mtext>J/(K·mol)</mtext></mfenced></math>

<math alttext="C H 3 O H, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="240, decimal point" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>240.</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="C O, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="198" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>198</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="131" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>131</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(i) Use the data in the table to calculate the value of the standard entropy change, <math alttext="delta S naught" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mtext mathvariant="italic">S</mtext><mtext>°</mtext></math>, in <math alttext="joules per kelvin mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>J/(K·mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></math>, for the reaction.

(ii) Calculate the value of <math alttext="delta G naught" overflow="scroll"><mtext>∆</mtext><mi>G</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>, for the reaction at <math alttext="375 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mn>375</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>. Assume that <math alttext="delta H naught" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>H</mi><mo>°</mo></math> and <math alttext="delta S naught" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>S</mi><mo>°</mo></math> are independent of temperature.

The following particle-level diagram shows a representative sample of the equilibrium mixture represented by the equation given.

(d) Use information from the particle diagram to calculate the partial pressure of <math alttext="C O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at equilibrium when the total pressure of the equilibrium mixture is <math alttext="12.0 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the reaction.

<math alttext="C H 3 O H, gas, is in equilibrium with C O, gas, plus 2 H 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CH</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mtext>OH(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>) </mtext><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mtext>⇄ </mtext><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mtext>CO(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo> </mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></math>
The reaction system represented by the equation is allowed to achieve equilibrium at a different temperature. The following table gives the partial pressure of each species in the equilibrium mixture.
SubstancePartial Pressure at Different Temperature<math alttext="C H 3 O H, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CH</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math><math alttext="2.7 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.7</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></math><math alttext="C O, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>CO</mi><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math><math alttext="4.2 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></math><math alttext="H 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math><math alttext="8.4 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8.4</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></math>
(f) Use the information in the table to calculate the value of the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, at the new temperature.

(g) The volume of the container is rapidly doubled with no change in temperature. As equilibrium is re-established, does the number of moles of <math alttext="C H 3 O H, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> increase, decrease, or remain the same? Justify your answer by comparing the value of the reaction quotient, <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, with the value of the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 3.B: Represent chemical substances or phenomena with appropriate diagrams or models (e.g., electron configuration).
